document.title: About
document.description: Powered by amazing open source projects.

body.raw:
## About

[ui.shadcn.com](https://ui.shadcn.com) is a project by [shadcn](https://shadcn.com).

## Credits

- [Radix UI](https://radix-ui.com) - For the primitives.
- [Vercel](https://vercel.com) - Where I host all my projects.
- [Shu Ding](https://shud.in) - The typography style is adapted from his work on Nextra.
- [Cal](https://cal.com) - Where I copied the styles for the first component: the `Button`.
- [cmdk](https://cmdk.paco.me) - For the `<Command />` component.

## License

MIT © [shadcn](https://shadcn.com)

document.title: Introduction
document.description: Simplify authentication with copy-paste ready code. Lightweight, customizable, and entirely yours to control.

body.raw:
This is **NOT** an authentication library in the traditional sense. Instead, it's a set of ready-to-use authentication components that you can copy and paste into your projects, whether they use Next.js.

**What do you mean by not a library?**

It means you don't need to install it as a dependency. AuthX isn't distributed through npm. You simply take the code you need, integrate it into your app, and customize it as you see fit. This approach gives you complete control over both the authentication flow and the user experience.

_Think of AuthX as a toolkit you can adapt to build your own authentication solution, without unnecessary dependencies._

## FAQ

<Accordion type="multiple">

<AccordionItem value="faq-1">
	<AccordionTrigger>
		Why copy/paste and not packaged as a dependency?
	</AccordionTrigger>
	<AccordionContent>
The main goal of AuthX is to give developers full control and flexibility. By copying the code directly into your project, you can customize it to your exact needs.

This approach avoids issues of tightly coupled styling and implementation that often come with packaged libraries. With AuthX, the design and flow of authentication can be tailored entirely to your application's requirements.
</AccordionContent>

</AccordionItem>

<AccordionItem value="faq-2">
  <AccordionTrigger>
    Will this ever be released as an npm package?
  </AccordionTrigger>
  <AccordionContent>
    No, AuthX is designed to be fully customizable by each developer. It's meant
    to be a foundational toolkit rather than a locked-in solution.
  </AccordionContent>
</AccordionItem>

<AccordionItem value="faq-3">
  <AccordionTrigger>Which frameworks are supported?</AccordionTrigger>
  <AccordionContent>
    AuthX is designed to work with any framework that supports JavaScript and
    Express-based servers, including Next.js.
  </AccordionContent>
</AccordionItem>

<AccordionItem value="faq-4">
  <AccordionTrigger>Can I use this in my project?</AccordionTrigger>
  <AccordionContent>
    Absolutely. AuthX is free for personal and commercial projects. No
    attribution is required, but feel free to share your projects with us— we'd
    love to see how you use AuthX!
  </AccordionContent>
</AccordionItem>

</Accordion>

---

## Quick Start

To get started with AuthX, simply follow these steps:

1. **Copy the example code**: Go to the [Quick Start Guide](#quick-start-guide) and copy the `auth.js` file into your project.
2. **Set up environment variables**: Ensure that your Google client ID, client secret, and app URL are configured correctly.
3. **Add authentication routes**: Use the provided API routes to handle login, logout, and callback.

By following this setup, you can have authentication up and running in minutes.

document.title: Installation
document.description: How to install dependencies and structure your app.

document.title: Manual Installation
document.description: Add dependencies to your project manually.

body.raw:
<Steps>

### Add dependencies

To get started with authentication, add the NextAuth package to your project by running the following command:

```bash
npm install next-auth
```

### Set Auth Options

Define your authentication options in authOptions. Here, you configure providers (such as Google or credentials), specify a session strategy, and handle authentication callbacks for sign-in, JWT, and session management.

```ts title="lib/auth/options.ts"
import { NextAuthOptions } from "next-auth";
import { ProviderGoogle } from "./providers/google";
import { ProviderCredentials } from "./providers/credentials";

export const authOptions: NextAuthOptions = {
  providers: [ProviderGoogle, ProviderCredentials],
  session: {
    strategy: "jwt",
  },
  callbacks: {
    async signIn({ user, account }) {
      return true;
    },
    async jwt({ token, user, account }) {
      if (user) {
        delete user["password"];
        token = { ...user };
        return token;
      }
      return token;
    },
    async session({ session, token }: any) {
      if (session.user && token) {
        session.user = token;
      }
      return session;
    },
  },
};
```

### Add Auth types

Extend NextAuth's types to ensure type safety throughout your authentication setup. This includes custom types for session, JWT, and user details (such as role, first name, and last name).

```ts title="lib/auth/next-auth.d.ts"
import NextAuth from "next-auth";
import { UserRole } from "@prisma/client";
import type { User } from "next-auth";
import "next-auth/jwt";

declare module "next-auth/jwt" {
  interface JWT extends User {}
}

declare module "next-auth" {
  interface Session {
    user: User & DefaultSession["user"];
  }

  interface User {
    id: string;
    role: UserRole;
    firstName: string;
    lastName: string;
    phone: string;
    password?: string;
  }
}
```

### Add Auth Functions

Create utility functions for authentication, including SignIn and SignOut for handling login and logout, useClientUser for accessing user data on the client, and GetServerUser to access user data on the server.

```ts title="lib/auth/index.ts"
import { getServerSession } from "next-auth";
import { BuiltInProviderType } from "next-auth/providers/index";
import {
  LiteralUnion,
  signIn,
  SignInAuthorizationParams,
  SignInOptions,
  signOut,
  useSession,
} from "next-auth/react";
import React from "react";
import { authOptions } from "./options";

export const SignIn = async (
  provider?: LiteralUnion<BuiltInProviderType> | undefined,
  options?: SignInOptions,
  authorizationParams?: SignInAuthorizationParams
) => {
  await signIn(provider, options, authorizationParams);
};

export const SignOut = async () => {
  await signOut();
};

export function useClientUser() {
  const [user, setUser] = React.useState();
  const { data: session } = useSession();

  React.useEffect(() => {
    if (session) {
      setUser(session.user as any);
    }
  }, [session]);

  return user;
}

export async function GetSeverUser() {
  const session = await getServerSession(authOptions);
  return session?.user;
}
```

### Add Session Provider

Wrap your application with the SessionProvider component to give components access to authentication data, such as the user's session. This provider enables use of NextAuth hooks, like useSession.

```ts title="lib/auth/AuthProviders.tsx"
"use client";
import { SessionProvider, SessionProviderProps } from "next-auth/react";

interface AuthProvidersProps extends SessionProviderProps {}

export default function AuthProviders({
  children,
  ...props
}: AuthProvidersProps) {
  return <SessionProvider {...props}>{children}</SessionProvider>;
}
```

### Wrap you App

Wrap your application with the AuthProviders component to provide authentication to components. This component is used in the app/layout.tsx file.

```ts title="app/layout.tsx"
<AuthProviders>{children}</AuthProviders>
```

### Add Google and other providers

Configure your authentication providers here. For Google, create a Google provider configuration using clientId and clientSecret. You can add other providers in this file as needed.

```ts title="lib/auth/providers/index.ts"
import GoogleProvider from "next-auth/providers/google";

export const ProviderGoogle = GoogleProvider({
  clientId: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID!,
  clientSecret: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET!,
});
```

### Set Env Variables

Add your Google OAuth credentials and other required environment variables. These variables enable authentication services to function correctly.

```bash title=".env.local"
GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID="client Id"
GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET="client secret"
REDIRECT_URI=http://localhost:3000/api/auth/callback
NEXTAUTH_SECRET="NEXTAUTH_SECRET"
NEXTAUTH_URL=http://localhost:3000
```

### Create Route Handler

Set up your authentication route in Next.js. This handler file configures the API route for NextAuth, enabling endpoints for user authentication.

```ts title="app/api/auth/[...nextauth]/route.ts"
import { authOptions } from "@/lib/auth/options";
import NextAuth from "next-auth/next";

const handler = NextAuth(authOptions);

export { handler as GET, handler as POST };
```

### That's it

You can now start adding components to your project.

</Steps>

    firstName: string;\r
    lastName: string;\r
    phone: string;\r
    password?: string;\r
  }\r
}

import { BuiltInProviderType } from "next-auth/providers/index";\r
import {\r
  LiteralUnion,\r
  signIn,\r
  SignInAuthorizationParams,\r
  SignInOptions,\r
  signOut,\r
  useSession,\r
} from "next-auth/react";\r
import React from "react";\r
import { authOptions } from "./options";\r
\r
export const SignIn = async (\r
  provider?: LiteralUnion<BuiltInProviderType> | undefined,\r
  options?: SignInOptions,\r
  authorizationParams?: SignInAuthorizationParams\r
) => {\r
  await signIn(provider, options, authorizationParams);\r
};\r
\r
export const SignOut = async () => {\r
  await signOut();\r
};\r
\r
export function useClientUser() {\r
  const [user, setUser] = React.useState();\r
  const { data: session } = useSession();\r
\r
  React.useEffect(() => {\r
    if (session) {\r
      setUser(session.user as any);\r
    }\r
  }, [session]);\r
\r
  return user;\r
}\r
\r
export async function GetSeverUser() {\r
  const session = await getServerSession(authOptions);\r
  return session?.user;\r
}
